case_name: Babu Lal v. Jairam and others

facts.text: Civil Appeal No.708 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.708 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated January 31, 1962 of Allahabad High Court in Civil Revision No. 60 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1962, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Revision No. 60 of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by SHAH, J. on September 18, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: September 18, 1963. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Jairam and three others sued Babu Lal in Court of Munsiff, Koil, District Aligarh for decree for possession of strip of land, removal of wall and slab of stone, injunction restraining constructions in northern wall of plaintiffs' house.

anchor.surface_text: Jairam and three others-hereafter companylectively called the plaintiffs-sued Babu Lal-appellant in this appeal-in the Court of the Munsiff, Koil, District Aligarh, for a decree for possession of a strip of land, for removal of a wall and a slab of stone and for an injunction restraining the making of certain companystructions in the numberthern wall of the plaintiffs house.

facts.text: Mohini wife of Jairam the first plaintiff purchased the house by sale deed dated August 1, 1932 from vendor named Mohini.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs claimed that Mohini wife of jairam the first plaintiff had purchased the house occupied by them by sale deed dated August 1, 1932 from the vendor who was also named Mohini, who in her turn had purchased the house by sale deed dated July 25, 1917 from the original owner Kishan Lal.

facts.text: Vendor Mohini purchased the house by sale deed dated July 25, 1917 from original owner Kishan Lal.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs claimed that Mohini wife of jairam the first plaintiff had purchased the house occupied by them by sale deed dated August 1, 1932 from the vendor who was also named Mohini, who in her turn had purchased the house by sale deed dated July 25, 1917 from the original owner Kishan Lal.

facts.text: Babu Lal is the son of Kishan Lal.

anchor.surface_text: Babu Lal who is the son of Kishan Lal pleaded that the vendor Mohini had acquired only a life interest in the house by the deed under which the property was companyveyed to her by Kishan Lal and the plaintiffs predecessor-ininterest had acquired numbertitle under the sale deed dated August 1, 1932.

facts.text: Babu Lal pleaded that vendor Mohini acquired only life interest in house by deed from Kishan Lal and plaintiffs' predecessor acquired no title under sale deed dated August 1, 1932.

anchor.surface_text: Babu Lal who is the son of Kishan Lal pleaded that the vendor Mohini had acquired only a life interest in the house by the deed under which the property was companyveyed to her by Kishan Lal and the plaintiffs predecessor-ininterest had acquired numbertitle under the sale deed dated August 1, 1932.

facts.text: Babu Lal gave evidence at trial and tendered agreement dated July 25, 1917 executed by Mohini reciting sale deed without consideration and life interest only.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this plea Babu Lal gave evidence at the trial of the suit and tendered in evidence an agreement dated July 25, 1917 purported to be executed by Mohini to whom Kishan Lal had companyveyed the house reciting that the sale deed in her favour was without companysideration and that she had only a life interest in the house.

facts.text: Trial judge held agreement relied on by Babu Lal not genuine and Mohini acquired title under sale deed dated August 1, 1932 and decreed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial judge held that the agreement relied upon by Babu Lal was number genuine and that Mohini, predecessor-in- interest of the plaintiffs had under the sale deed dated August 1, 1932 acquired title to the house in dispute and on that footing decreed the suit.

facts.text: In appeal to District Court, finding that agreement not genuine was not challenged.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the District Court the finding that the agreement was number genuine was number challenged.

facts.text: Plaintiffs applied under s.479A CrPC against Babu Lal for giving false evidence, forging agreement, fabricating false evidence, using fabricated evidence, offences u/ss.193,209,463,471 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Before the suit was disposed of by the Munsiff the plaintiffs had applied that action be taken against Babu Lal under s. 479A of the Code of Criminal Procedure, because Babu Lal had given false evidence before the Court, that he had forged the agreement relied upon by him, and that he had fabricated false evidence and had used such fabricated evidence at the trial, and had thereby companymitted offences punishable under ss. 193, 209, 463 and 471 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Munsiff did not dispose of the s.479A application by judgment deciding the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsiff did number dispose of the application by his judgment deciding the suit.

facts.text: After disposal of suit, plaintiffs moved Munsiff for order on the application.

anchor.surface_text: After the disposal of the suit the plaintiffs moved the Munsiff for an order on the application filed by them.

facts.text: Munsiff held no action could be taken under s.479A for intentionally giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence as barred, but expedient in interest of justice to file complaint u/ss.463 and 471 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsiff held that numberaction companyld be taken against Babu Lal for the offence of intentionally giving false evidence or intentionally fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used in the suit for such action was barred by s. 479A Code of Criminal Procedure, but in his opinion it was expedient in the interest of justice that a companyplaint be filed against Babu Lal for offences under ss. 463 and 471 I.P. Code.

facts.text: Pursuant to Munsiff order, complaint filed on May 30, 1959 against Babu Lal u/s.471 r/w s.463 IPC for using agreement dated July 25, 1917 knowing it forged.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this order on May 30, 1959 a companyplaint was filed against Babu Lal charging him with companymitting an offence under s. 471 read with s. 463 Indian Penal Code by using the agreement dated July 25, 1917 knowing or having reason to believe that it was a forged document.

facts.text: Order passed by Trial Court confirmed in appeal by District Judge, Aligarh.

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by Trial Court was companyfirmed in appeal by the District Judge, Aligarh and a revision application to the High Court of Allahabad challenging the order was dismissed.

facts.text: Revision application to High Court of Allahabad challenging the order dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by Trial Court was companyfirmed in appeal by the District Judge, Aligarh and a revision application to the High Court of Allahabad challenging the order was dismissed.

facts.text: Babu Lal appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, Babu Lal has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Munsiff opined the agreement dated July 25, 1917 was a forged document.

anchor.surface_text: In the opinion of the Munsiff the document was a forged document.

facts.text: Munsiff did not record in judgment opinion that expedient to prosecute Babu Lal for intentionally giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence under s.479A.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsiff however by his judgment disposing of the suit did number record an opinion that it was expedient for the eradication of the evils of perjury and fabrication of false evidence, and in the interests of justice to prosecute Babu Lal for the offence of intentionally giving false evidence, or for intentionally fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used at any stage of the judicial proceeding.

facts.text: Trial Court directed complaint under s.476 CrPC for offence of using forged document u/s.471 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court accepted this restriction upon its jurisdiction and directed in exercise of the powers vested under S. 476 Criminal Procedure Code the making of a companyplaint of an offence of fraudulently or dishonestly using as genuine a document which Babu Lai knew or had reason to believe to be a forged document.

facts.text: Babu Lal was examined as witness in civil suit and tendered agreement dated July 25, 1917.

anchor.surface_text: Babu Lal was examined as a witness in the Civil suit filed by the plaintiffs. He tendered in evidence the agreement dated July 25, 1917.

anchor.surface_text: tendered in evidence an agreement dated July 25, 1917 purported to be executed by Mohini to whom Kishan Lal had companyveyed the house reciting that the sale deed in her favour was without companysideration and that she had only a life interest in the house.

facts.text: In District Court appeal, finding on agreement genuineness admitted implicitly as not challenged.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter XXXV of the Code of Criminal Procedure prescribes the procedure to be followed for prosecution of offenders in case of certain offences affecting the administration of justice.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provisions for prosecution in offences affecting administration of justice

anchor.surface_text: Section 476 sets out the procedure for prosecution of offenders for offences enumerated in s. 195 1  b   c  of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

concepts.unlisted_description: Offences relating to contempt of lawful authority of public servants, forgery etc. in judicial proceedings

anchor.surface_text: If a Civil, Revenue or Criminal Court is of opinion, that it is expedient in the interests of justice that an enquiry be made into any offence referred to in s. 195 1  b  or  c  which appears to have been companymitted in or in relation to proceeding in that Court, such Court may, after such preliminary inquiry, if any, as it thinks necessary, record a finding to that effect and make a companyplaint thereof in writing and forward the same to a Magistrate of the first class having jurisdiction.

concepts.interpretation: General procedure for certain offences affecting administration of justice.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: on application to the High Court of Allahabad challenging the order was dismissed. With special leave, Babu Lal has appealed to this Court. Chapter XX

anchor.surface_text: Section 476A authorises a superior Court to make a companyplaint where a Subordinate Court has omitted to do so in respect of offences and in the circumstances mentioned in s. 476 1 .

concepts.unlisted_description: Superior court complaint when subordinate omits

anchor.surface_text: Section 476B provides for a right of appeal against the order making or refusing to make companyplaint.
Sections 478 and 479 deal with the procedure which may be followed in certain grave cases.
Sections 478 and 479 deal with the procedure which may be followed in certain grave cases.

Section 479A which was added by the Code of Criminal Procedure  Amendment  Act 26 of 1955 by the first sub- section  insofar as it is material  provides Notwithstanding anything companytained in sections 476 to 479 inclusive, when any Civil, Revenue or Criminal Court is of opinion that any person appearing before it as a witness has intentionally given false evidence in any stage of the judicial proceeding or has intentionally fabricated false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of the judicial proceeding, and that, for the eradication of the evils of perjury and fabrication of false evidence and in the interests of justice, it is expedient that such witness should be prosecuted for the offence which appears to have been companymitted by him, the Court shall, at the time of the delivery of the judgment or final order disposing of such proceeding, record a finding to that effect stating its reasons therefor and may, if it so thinks fit, after giving the witness an opportunity of being heard, make a companyplaint thereof in writing signed by the presiding officer of the Court setting forth the evidence which, in the opinion of the Court, is false or fabricated and forward the same to a Magistrate of the first class having jurisdiction, and may And sub-s.  6  enacts that No proceedings shall be taken under sections 476 to 479 inclusive for the prosecution of a person for giving or fabricating false evidence, if in respect of such a person proceedings may be taken under this section.

concepts.interpretation: Exclusive procedure for witness giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence; must record opinion at time of judgment; sub-s.6 bars ss.476-479 for those offences.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ation of the evils of perjury and fabrication of false evidence and in the interests of justice, it is expedient that such witness should be prosecute

anchor.surface_text: The phraseology used in s. 479A is plain and unambiguous it excludes the jurisdiction of the Court to proceed under ss. 476 to 479, in respect of offences specified in s. 195 1   b   c  of the Code of Criminal Procedure only where a person appearing before the Court as a witness has intentionally given false evidence in any stage of the judicial proceeding or has intentionally fabricated false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of the judicial proceeding. An offence punishable under s. 471 Indian Penal Code being one of fraudulently or dishonestly using as genuine any document which the accused knows or has reason to believe to be a forged document, does number fall within the category companytemplated by s. 479A 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure and therefore the authority of the Court to act under s. 476 of the Code is impaired by sub-s.  6  of s. 479A.

concepts.interpretation: Offence under s.471 IPC not covered by s.479A(1); proceedings under s.476 permissible.

concepts.interpretation: Definition of fabricating false evidence requires intent for use in judicial proceeding to form erroneous opinion.

issues.text: Whether sub-section (6) of section 479A CrPC bars the court from taking proceedings under sections 476 to 479 CrPC for prosecution of a person for an offence under section 471 IPC where such person appeared as a witness and used a forged document.

anchor.surface_text: The phraseology used in s. 479A is plain and unambiguous it excludes the jurisdiction of the Court to proceed under ss. 476 to 479, in respect of offences specified in s. 195 1   b   c  of the Code of Criminal Procedure only where a person appearing before the Court as a witness has intentionally given false evidence in any stage of the judicial proceeding or has intentionally fabricated false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of the judicial proceeding. An offence punishable under s. 471 Indian Penal Code being one of fraudulently or dishonestly using as genuine any document which the accused knows or has reason to believe to be a forged document, does number fall within the category contemplated by s. 479A 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure and therefore the authority of the Court to act under s. 476 of the Code is impaired by sub-s.  6  of s. 479A.

issues.text: Whether the offence of forgery under sections 463 and 464 IPC or using as genuine a forged document under section 471 IPC falls within the category of intentionally fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used in a judicial proceeding as contemplated by section 479A(1) CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that some of the ingredients of the act of fabricating false evidence which is penalised under s. 193 Indian Penal Code and of making a false document and thereby committing forgery within the meaning of ss. 463 and 464 Indian Penal Code are common. A person by making a false entry in any book or record or by making any document containing a false statement may, if the prescribed conditions of s. 463 are fulfilled, commit an offence of forgery. But the important ingredient which constitutes fabrication of false evidence within the meaning of s. 192 Indian Penal Code besides causing a circumstance to exist or making a false document-to use a compendious expression-is the intention that the circumstance so caused to exist or the false document made may appear in evidence in a judicial proceeding, or before a public servant or before an arbitrator, and lead to the forming of an erroneous opinion touching any point material to the result of the proceeding.

issues.text: Whether a court can record a finding and make a complaint under section 479A CrPC for intentionally giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence after the delivery of the judgment or final order disposing of the proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: Babu Lal was examined as a witness in the Civil suit filed by the plaintiffs. He tendered in evidence the agreement dated July 25, 1917. In the opinion of the Munsiff the document was a forged document. The Munsiff however by his judgment disposing of the suit did number record an opinion that it was expedient for the eradication of the evils of perjury and fabrication of false evidence, and in the interests of justice to prosecute Babu Lal for the offence of intentionally giving false evidence, or for intentionally fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used at any stage of the judicial proceeding. He could number therefore after the disposal of the suit make a complaint for the offence of giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence.

arguments.claim: Complaint for offence under s.471 IPC may only be made under s.479A CrPC and not otherwise

arguments.court_reasoning: Phraseology of s.479A plain; applies only to intentionally giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence, not s.471 using forged document

arguments.claim: s.479A(6) bars proceedings under ss.476-479 only where case falls within s.479A(1) for witness intentionally giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the terms of sub-s. 6 that the procedure prescribed thereby alone applies if the case falls within sub-s. 1 . But sub-s. 1 has a limited operation it applies only to the prosecution of a witness appearing before the Court,

arguments.claim: Offence under s.471 IPC of using forged document as genuine does not fall within s.479A(1)

anchor.surface_text: An offence punishable under s. 471 Indian Penal Code being one of fraudulently or dishonestly using as genuine any document which the accused knows or has reason to believe to be a forged document, does not fall within the category contemplated by s. 479A 1 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

arguments.claim: s.479A special procedure only for giving false evidence or fabrication of false evidence under s.193 IPC etc., not other offences like forgery or using forged document
arguments.court_reasoning: Citing Raghubir Prosad Dudhtvalla v. Chamanlal Mehra

arguments.claim: Fabricating false evidence under s.192 IPC distinct from forgery under ss.463/464 IPC; requires specific intent for erroneous opinion in proceeding
s.479A not applicable to s.471 IPC offence of using forged document; resort only to s.476 CrPC
Mention of s.471 in Shabir Hussain was oversight; s.479A exclusive only for intentionally giving false evidence

holdings.text: The phraseology of s.479A CrPC excludes jurisdiction under ss.476-479 only for cases of witness intentionally giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence; offence under s.471 IPC does not fall within that category and thus s.476 proceedings are not barred by s.479A(6).

anchor.surface_text: The phraseology used in s. 479A is plain and unambiguous it excludes the jurisdiction of the Court to proceed under ss. 476 to 479, in respect of offences specified in s. 195 1   b   c  of the Code of Criminal Procedure only where a person appearing before the Court as a witness has intentionally given false evidence in any stage of the judicial proceeding or has intentionally fabricated false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of the judicial proceeding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.479A(1) and (6); s.471 requires using forged document knowing it forged, distinct from giving false evidence or fabrication; supported by precedent in Raghubir Prosad.

holdings.text: Offence of forgery under ss.463/464 IPC or using forged document under s.471 IPC does not constitute 'intentionally fabricating false evidence' under s.479A(1) CrPC as it lacks the specific intent to cause circumstance or document to appear in evidence leading to erroneous opinion on material point.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction based on statutory definitions in ss.192,193,463,464 IPC; common ingredients but fabrication requires unique intent for misleading judicial proceeding; s.471 even less so as it is using, not making.

holdings.text: A court cannot record finding or make complaint under s.479A CrPC for intentionally giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence after delivery of judgment disposing of the proceeding, as it must be done at the time of judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsiff however by his judgment disposing of the suit did number record an opinion that it was expedient for the eradication of the evils of perjury and fabrication of false evidence, and in the interests of justice to prosecute Babu Lal for the offence of intentionally giving false evidence, or for intentionally fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used at any stage of the judicial proceeding. He could number therefore after the disposal of the suit make a complaint for the offence of giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory language in s.479A(1) requires recording finding 'at the time of the delivery of the judgment or final order'; Munsiff failed to do so, barring later action.

holdings.text: Special procedure under s.479A CrPC applies only to prosecution for giving false evidence (s.193 IPC) or fabrication (s.192 IPC), not precluding other procedures like s.476 for other offences affecting administration of justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct quote and application from precedent Raghubir Prosad Dudhtvalla v. Chamanlal Mehra; s.479A has limited operation to specific acts punishable under s.193 and cognate sections.

holdings.text: Observation in Shabir Hussain v. State of Maharashtra including s.471 IPC within exclusive operation of s.479A was by oversight and incorrect.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of earlier observation in Shabir Hussain limited to false evidence; inclusion of s.471 inadvertent.

precedents.citation: Raghubir Prosad Dudhtvalla v. Chamanlal Mehra and another 1

anchor.surface_text: Raghubir Prosad Dudhtvalla v. Chamanlal Mehra and another 1 observed The special procedure of s. 479A is prescribed only for the prosecution of a witness for the act of giving false evidence in any stage of judicial proceeding or for fabrication of false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding.

precedents.case_name: Raghubir Prosad Dudhtvalla v. Chamanlal Mehra
precedents.cited_proposition: The special procedure of s. 479A is prescribed only for the prosecution of a witness for the act of giving false evidence in any stage of judicial proceeding or for fabrication of false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding. There is nothing in the section which precludes the application of any other procedure prescribed by the Code in respect of other offences.
precedents.cited_holding: special procedure of s. 479A is prescribed only for the prosecution of a witness for the act of giving false evidence or fabrication of false evidence; does not include forgery or s.471 IPC

precedents.citation: Shabir Hussain Bholu v. State of Maharashtra 1

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 476 is a general provision; exclusive operation of s. 479A restricted to intentionally giving false evidence; mention of s.471 was by oversight
precedents.cited_holding: whereas s. 476 is a general provision... in so far as certain offences falling under ss. 193 to 195... can alone make a complaint (s.471 mention by oversight)

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal against the order directing filing of complaint under s. 476 CrPC for offence u/s 471 IPC dismissed; lower courts' orders upheld.

edges.explanation: Argument clarifies s.479A exclusivity to intentionally giving false evidence (s.471 mention oversight) addresses issue of whether forgery/s.471 constitutes fabricating false evidence.

edges.explanation: Argument a2 that no action under s.479A for false evidence if finding not recorded at judgment time addresses i3 on post-judgment complaints.
Argument affirming s.476 applicability for s.471 offence since not barred supports the concept c9.
Argument that s.479A(6) does not bar s.476 for s.471 supports the holding's interpretation limiting the bar.
Argument that s.476 applicable for s.471 as s.479A(6) does not bar directly addresses the core issue i1.
Argument restricting s.471 to s.479A attacks the argument permitting s.476 for s.471.
Argument insisting s.471 only under s.479A rebuts the concept of using s.476 for s.471.

anchor.surface_text: The phraseology used in s. 479A is plain and unambiguous it excludes the jurisdiction of the Court to proceed under ss. 476 to 479, in respect of offences specified in s. 195 1   b   c  of the Code of Criminal Procedure only where a person appearing before the Court as a witness has intentionally given false evidence in any stage of the judicial proceeding or has intentionally fabricated false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of the judicial proceeding.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsiff however by his judgment disposing of the suit did number record an opinion that it was expedient for the eradication of the evils of perjury and fabrication of false evidence, and in the interests of justice to prosecute Babu Lal for the offence of intentionally giving false evidence, or for intentionally fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used at any stage of the judicial proceeding. He could number therefore after the disposal of the suit make a complaint for the offence of giving false evidence or fabricating false evidence.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed.
